A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.

A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called free or linearly independent if from an equation sum_{i in I} a_i x_i = 0 with coefficients a_i in A we can conclude that a_i = 0 for all i in I. A free system of generators will also be referred to as a basis.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Free system of generators (basis) to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Free system of generators (basis) specifically refers to an A-module M. An A-module, by definition, is a generalization of the concept of a vector space, where the scalars (coefficients) belong to a ring A instead of a field. This means that the elements a_i in the definition of a free system of generators are elements of a ring A. Therefore, the concept of a ring is fundamental to defining what an A-module is, and consequently, it is essential for defining a free system of generators (basis) for such a module. Without the concept of a ring, the notion of an A-module and hence the concept of a free system of generators (basis) would not be well-defined or meaningful.
